data.title: R&B Artists & Singers List
data.meta_description: Hey there, music lovers! Are you looking for some smooth R&B tunes to add to your playlist? Well, look no further because we've got you covered with our Full A to Z R&B Artists Directory! This comprehensive directory is your one-stop-shop for all things R&B, featuring a variety of talented artists who will leave you
data.meta_site_name: Singersroom.com - R&B Music, R&B Videos, R&B News
data.text:
Hey there, music lovers! Are you looking for some smooth R&B tunes to add to your playlist? Well, look no further because we’ve got you covered with our Full A to Z R&B Artists Directory! This comprehensive directory is your one-stop-shop for all things R&B, featuring a variety of talented artists who will leave you feeling soulful and swaying to the rhythm of their tunes.

From the classic sounds of Marvin Gaye to the modern hits of Beyoncé, our singers directory has it all. Each artist has their own unique style and flair, bringing a fresh twist to the R&B genre. So whether you’re in the mood for some slow and seductive ballads or upbeat and funky jams, our directory has something for everyone.

And don’t worry if you’re new to the R&B scene, our directory includes many up-and-coming singers as well, who are sure to make a splash in the industry. So you can be the first to discover and share their amazing music with your friends.

So what are you waiting for? Take a stroll through our directory, and let the smooth sounds of R&B wash over you. It’s time to get lost in the music and let the rhythm guide you to a world of soulful bliss.

>> CLICK HERE TO BROWSE FULL A-Z DIRECTORY

The Greatest R&B Artists of All Time

1. Whitney Houston

Whitney Houston was an iconic singer and actress who rose to fame in the 1980s and became one of the most successful and beloved R&B artists of all time. With her powerful voice and undeniable talent, Houston captivated audiences around the world and set a new standard for vocal excellence.

Houston’s hits, including “I Will Always Love You,” “Saving All My Love for You,” and “How Will I Know,” showcased her range and versatility as a singer. Her music was a blend of R&B, pop, and gospel, and her emotional delivery and impeccable phrasing left an indelible mark on the industry.

In addition to her music, Whitney Houston was also a successful actress, starring in films such as “The Bodyguard” and “Waiting to Exhale.” She was a trailblazer for women in the entertainment industry and paved the way for future generations of artists.

Despite her untimely death in 2012, Whitney Houston’s music and legacy continue to inspire and influence new generations of fans and artists alike. Her impact on R&B and pop music will always be remembered, and her voice will always be considered one of the greatest in music history.

2. Marvin Gaye

Marvin Gaye was a legendary musician who was known for his soulful and smooth R&B sound. His powerful voice, coupled with his ability to write and produce his own music, set him apart from other artists of his time. Marvin Gaye’s music was not only a reflection of his own experiences, but also a commentary on the social and political issues of his era.

Gaye began his career in the 1960s as a Motown artist, where he quickly rose to fame with hits like “Ain’t No Mountain High Enough” and “How Sweet It Is (To Be Loved By You).” However, it was his later work, such as the album “What’s Going On,” that cemented his legacy as one of the greatest R&B artists of all time.

Throughout his career, Marvin Gaye’s music explored themes of love, heartbreak, and social justice. He was a pioneer in the genre and his influence can still be heard in the music of contemporary R&B artists. Marvin Gaye’s impact on music is immeasurable, and his legacy will continue to inspire generations to come.

3. Stevie Wonder

Stevie Wonder is a legendary musician and songwriter who has been a mainstay in the world of R&B and soul for decades. Blind since birth, Wonder’s remarkable talent for music has earned him countless accolades and a dedicated fanbase.

With hits like “Superstition,” “I Just Called to Say I Love You,” and “Signed, Sealed, Delivered,” Wonder’s music is characterized by his soulful voice, incredible musicianship, and powerful lyrics. His ability to seamlessly blend genres, from R&B to funk to pop, has earned him a reputation as one of the most versatile artists of his time.

Stevie Wonder’s music has always been a reflection of his personal experiences and a commentary on social issues. He has used his platform to advocate for causes such as civil rights, disability rights, and environmentalism. In addition to his music, Wonder is also a talented instrumentalist, playing a variety of instruments including the harmonica, piano, and drums.

Throughout his long and storied career, Stevie Wonder has left an indelible mark on the world of R&B and soul music. His influence can be heard in the music of countless artists who have followed in his footsteps. He is truly a musical icon and a testament to the power of music to inspire and uplift.

4. Prince

Prince was a groundbreaking musician, songwriter, and producer who left an indelible mark on the world of R&B and rock music. Known for his flamboyant style, raw talent, and enigmatic personality, Prince’s music pushed the boundaries of genre and challenged conventional notions of masculinity.

With hits like “Purple Rain,” “Kiss,” and “When Doves Cry,” Prince’s music was a blend of funk, R&B, rock, and pop, often infused with provocative lyrics and imagery. His live performances were legendary, showcasing his impressive guitar skills and dynamic stage presence.

Prince was not only a musical genius, but also a trailblazer in the industry. He fought for creative control of his music and paved the way for independent artists to have greater agency in their careers. His influence can be heard in the music of countless contemporary R&B and rock artists.

Despite his untimely death in 2016, Prince’s music and legacy continue to inspire and captivate audiences around the world. He was a true iconoclast who refused to be pigeonholed and will always be remembered as one of the most influential and innovative musicians of all time.

5. Aretha Franklin

Aretha Franklin, known as the “Queen of Soul,” was a legendary musician and singer whose powerful voice and soulful delivery captivated audiences around the world. Her music, which blended gospel, R&B, and pop, broke down barriers and established her as one of the most influential artists of her time.

Franklin’s hits, including “Respect,” “Chain of Fools,” and “Think,” became anthems for a generation and cemented her place in music history. Her music was not only a reflection of her personal experiences, but also a commentary on the social and political issues of her time.

In addition to her music, Aretha Franklin was a trailblazer for women in the music industry. She was the first woman to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and won numerous Grammy awards throughout her career. Her influence can be heard in the music of countless contemporary R&B and soul artists.

Aretha Franklin’s legacy continues to inspire and uplift audiences around the world. Her music was a testament to the power of the human voice and the ability of music to connect people across cultures and generations. She will always be remembered as one of the greatest singers and musicians of all time.

6. Michael Jackson

Michael Jackson, known as the “King of Pop,” was one of the most iconic and influential artists of all time. He rose to fame as a member of the Jackson 5 and later embarked on a successful solo career. Jackson’s unique blend of R&B, pop, and rock music, coupled with his electrifying dance moves, captivated audiences around the world.

Jackson’s music was a reflection of his personal life and experiences, with hits like “Billie Jean,” “Beat It,” and “Thriller” becoming anthems of a generation. He was a masterful storyteller who used his music to address important social issues, such as racial inequality and environmental awareness.

In addition to his music, Michael Jackson was also known for his philanthropic work, particularly in the area of children’s charities. He was a trailblazer in the entertainment industry, breaking down barriers and paving the way for future generations of R&B and pop artists.

Despite his untimely death in 2009, Michael Jackson’s music and legacy continue to inspire and influence new generations of fans and artists alike. His impact on music, dance, and popular culture will always be remembered.

7. The Temptations

The Temptations were a legendary R&B group known for their soulful harmonies, smooth dance moves, and dynamic stage presence. With hits like “My Girl,” “Papa Was a Rolling Stone,” and “Ain’t Too Proud to Beg,” the Temptations defined the sound of Motown and became one of the most successful and influential groups of their time.

Formed in the early 1960s, the Temptations quickly rose to fame with their signature sound and impeccable choreography. They were known for their sharp suits, synchronized dance moves, and undeniable charisma, which made them one of the most popular live acts of the era.

Despite several lineup changes over the years, the Temptations continued to produce hits and maintain their status as one of the most iconic groups in R&B history. Their music was a blend of R&B, soul, funk, and pop, and their lyrics often addressed social and political issues of the time.

The Temptations’ impact on R&B and popular music cannot be overstated. Their influence can be heard in the music of countless contemporary R&B and soul artists, and their legacy continues to inspire new generations of fans and musicians. They will always be remembered as one of the greatest groups of all time.

8. Ray Charles

Ray Charles was a musical pioneer who revolutionized R&B and soul music with his unique style and sound. Known for his distinctive voice, masterful piano playing, and innovative arrangements, Charles’ music blended gospel, blues, jazz, and R&B, creating a new genre that influenced generations of artists.

With hits like “What’d I Say,” “Georgia on My Mind,” and “Hit the Road Jack,” Ray Charles’ music was a blend of emotion, energy, and soulfulness that captivated audiences around the world. His music was not only a reflection of his own experiences, but also a commentary on the social and political issues of his time.

In addition to his music, Ray Charles was also a trailblazer for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. He was one of the first black musicians to achieve mainstream success, and his influence paved the way for future generations of artists.

Despite his passing in 2004, Ray Charles’ music and legacy continue to inspire and influence new generations of fans and artists alike. He will always be remembered as a musical icon who pushed the boundaries of genre and created a sound that will forever be associated with the soul of America.

9. James Brown

James Brown, also known as the “Godfather of Soul,” was a legendary musician and performer who defined the sound of R&B and funk in the 1960s and 1970s. With hits like “I Got You (I Feel Good),” “Papa’s Got a Brand New Bag,” and “Sex Machine,” Brown’s music was a potent mix of raw energy, soulful vocals, and infectious rhythms that had audiences dancing and singing along.

Brown’s innovative approach to music, including his use of syncopated rhythms, call-and-response vocals, and frenzied stage performances, influenced countless musicians across genres. His music was not only a reflection of his own experiences but also addressed issues of social and political importance, such as civil rights and African American identity.

In addition to his music, James Brown was also a trailblazer for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. He was one of the first black musicians to achieve crossover success and became an icon of Black pride and empowerment.

Despite his passing in 2006, James Brown’s music and legacy continue to inspire and influence new generations of fans and artists alike. He will always be remembered as one of the most innovative and influential figures in the history of R&B and funk music.

10. Sam Cooke

Sam Cooke was a talented singer and songwriter who left an indelible mark on the R&B and soul music scene in the 1950s and 1960s. Known for his smooth, silky voice and his ability to blend gospel, R&B, and pop music, Cooke produced a string of hits, including “You Send Me,” “A Change Is Gonna Come,” and “Cupid.”

Cooke’s music was a reflection of his own experiences, as well as a commentary on the social and political issues of his time. His soulful vocals and poignant lyrics captured the struggles and hopes of the African American community during the civil rights movement.

In addition to his music, Sam Cooke was also a trailblazer for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. He founded his own record label and publishing company, which allowed him to maintain creative control over his music and helped pave the way for other black artists to do the same.

Despite his untimely death in 1964, Sam Cooke’s music and legacy continue to inspire and influence new generations of fans and artists alike. He will always be remembered as one of the most important and influential voices in the history of R&B and soul music.

11. Luther Vandross

Luther Vandross was a legendary R&B singer and songwriter known for his silky smooth voice and romantic ballads. With hits like “Here and Now,” “Dance with My Father,” and “Never Too Much,” Vandross captured the hearts of audiences around the world with his soulful vocals and heartfelt lyrics.

Vandross’ music was a reflection of his own experiences and emotions, as well as a celebration of love and relationships. His ability to convey complex emotions through his music, coupled with his impeccable vocal technique, made him one of the most beloved and influential R&B artists of his generation.

In addition to his music, Luther Vandross was also a trailblazer for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. He was one of the first black artists to achieve crossover success and became an icon of Black excellence and achievement.

Despite his passing in 2005, Luther Vandross’ music and legacy continue to inspire and influence new generations of fans and artists alike. He will always be remembered as one of the most talented and beloved R&B singers of all time.

12. Al Green

Al Green is a legendary soul and R&B singer known for his smooth, silky voice and romantic ballads. With hits like “Let’s Stay Together,” “Love and Happiness,” and “Tired of Being Alone,” Green’s music has been a staple of R&B radio stations for decades.

Green’s music was a reflection of his own experiences and emotions, as well as a celebration of love, faith, and spirituality. His soulful vocals and heartfelt lyrics made him one of the most beloved and influential R&B artists of his generation.

In addition to his music, Al Green was also a trailblazer for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. He was one of the first black artists to achieve mainstream success and became an icon of Black excellence and achievement.

Despite his later transition to gospel music, Al Green’s contributions to R&B and soul music are still celebrated today. He will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential singers of his generation, and a true legend of R&B music.

13. The Isley Brothers

The Isley Brothers are an iconic R&B and soul group that have been making music for over six decades. With hits like “Shout,” “Twist and Shout,” and “This Old Heart of Mine (Is Weak for You),” the Isleys’ music has been a staple of R&B radio stations since the 1950s.

The Isley Brothers’ music was a reflection of their own experiences and emotions, as well as a celebration of love, relationships, and good times. Their soulful vocals and catchy melodies made them one of the most beloved and influential R&B groups of their time.

In addition to their music, the Isley Brothers were also trailblazers for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. They founded their own record label and publishing company, which allowed them to maintain creative control over their music and helped pave the way for other black artists to do the same.

Despite changes in the music industry and the passing of several members, the Isley Brothers continue to make music and tour, inspiring and entertaining audiences around the world. They will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential R&B groups of all time.

14. Otis Redding

Otis Redding was a legendary soul singer and songwriter known for his powerful vocals and emotive performances. With hits like “(Sittin’ On) The Dock of the Bay,” “Try a Little Tenderness,” and “I’ve Been Loving You Too Long,” Redding’s music has been a staple of soul and R&B radio stations for decades.

Redding’s music was a reflection of his own experiences and emotions, as well as a commentary on the social and political issues of his time. His soulful vocals and heartfelt lyrics captured the struggles and hopes of the African American community during the civil rights movement.

In addition to his music, Otis Redding was also a trailblazer for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. He was one of the first black artists to achieve crossover success and became an icon of Black excellence and achievement.

Despite his untimely death in 1967, Otis Redding’s music and legacy continue to inspire and influence new generations of fans and artists alike. He will always be remembered as one of the most important and influential voices in the history of soul and R&B music.

15. The Jackson 5

The Jackson 5, also known as the Jacksons, are an iconic R&B and pop group that rose to fame in the 1970s. With hits like “ABC,” “I Want You Back,” and “Dancing Machine,” the Jackson 5’s music has been a staple of pop and R&B radio stations for decades.

The Jackson 5’s music was a reflection of their youthful energy and enthusiasm, as well as a celebration of love, relationships, and good times. Their catchy melodies and synchronized dance moves made them one of the most beloved and influential groups of their time.

In addition to their music, the Jackson 5 were also trailblazers for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. They broke down barriers and stereotypes, becoming one of the first black groups to achieve mainstream success and helping pave the way for other black artists to do the same.

Despite changes in the music industry and the passing of several members, the Jacksons continue to perform and tour, inspiring and entertaining audiences around the world. They will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential groups in the history of R&B and pop music.

16. Smokey Robinson

Smokey Robinson is a legendary singer, songwriter, and record producer known for his smooth vocals and emotive performances. With hits like “Tracks of My Tears,” “Cruisin’,” and “Being with You,” Robinson’s music has been a staple of R&B and soul radio stations for decades.

Robinson’s music was a reflection of his own experiences and emotions, as well as a commentary on the human condition. His soulful vocals and heartfelt lyrics captured the struggles and joys of love, relationships, and personal growth, making him one of the most beloved and influential artists of his time.

In addition to his music, Smokey Robinson was also a trailblazer for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. He founded his own record label and publishing company, which allowed him to maintain creative control over his music and helped pave the way for other black artists to do the same.

Despite changes in the music industry and the passing of time, Smokey Robinson continues to make music and tour, inspiring and entertaining audiences around the world. He will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential voices in the history of R&B and soul music.

17. Boyz II Men

Boyz II Men is a legendary R&B vocal group known for their soulful harmonies and emotional ballads. With hits like “End of the Road,” “I’ll Make Love to You,” and “One Sweet Day,” Boyz II Men’s music has been a staple of R&B and pop radio stations for decades.

Boyz II Men’s music was a reflection of their own experiences and emotions, as well as a celebration of love, relationships, and personal growth. Their intricate harmonies and heartfelt lyrics captured the hearts of fans around the world, making them one of the most successful and beloved R&B groups of all time.

In addition to their music, Boyz II Men were also trailblazers for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. They broke down barriers and stereotypes, becoming one of the first black groups to achieve mainstream success and helping pave the way for other black artists to do the same.

Despite changes in the music industry and the passing of time, Boyz II Men continues to make music and tour, inspiring and entertaining audiences around the world. They will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential vocal groups in the history of R&B and pop music.

18. Kool and the Gang

Kool and the Gang is an iconic R&B and funk group known for their infectious beats and upbeat melodies. With hits like “Celebration,” “Jungle Boogie,” and “Get Down On It,” Kool and the Gang’s music has been a staple of dance floors and radio stations for decades.

Kool and the Gang’s music was a reflection of their own experiences and emotions, as well as a celebration of life, love, and good times. Their groovy rhythms and catchy hooks made them one of the most successful and influential R&B and funk groups of their time.

In addition to their music, Kool and the Gang were also trailblazers for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. They broke down barriers and stereotypes, becoming one of the first black groups to achieve mainstream success and helping pave the way for other black artists to do the same.

Despite changes in the music industry and the passing of time, Kool and the Gang continues to perform and tour, inspiring and entertaining audiences around the world. They will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential groups in the history of R&B and funk music.

19. Teddy Pendergrass

Teddy Pendergrass was a legendary R&B singer known for his smooth vocals and passionate performances. With hits like “Love T.K.O.,” “Close the Door,” and “Turn Off the Lights,” Pendergrass’s music has been a staple of soul and R&B radio stations for decades.

Pendergrass’s music was a reflection of his own experiences and emotions, as well as a celebration of love, relationships, and sensuality. His soulful vocals and romantic lyrics captured the hearts of fans around the world, making him one of the most beloved and influential R&B singers of all time.

In addition to his music, Teddy Pendergrass was also a trailblazer for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. He broke down barriers and stereotypes, becoming one of the first black male singers to achieve mainstream success and helping pave the way for other black artists to do the same.

Despite a tragic accident that left him paralyzed, Pendergrass continued to make music and inspire audiences until his passing in 2010. He will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential voices in the history of R&B and soul music.

20. New Edition

New Edition is an iconic R&B group known for their tight harmonies and catchy pop songs. With hits like “Candy Girl,” “Cool It Now,” and “If It Isn’t Love,” New Edition’s music has been a staple of R&B and pop radio stations for decades.

New Edition’s music was a reflection of their own experiences and emotions, as well as a celebration of love, relationships, and growing up. Their catchy melodies and upbeat lyrics made them one of the most successful and influential R&B groups of their time.

In addition to their music, New Edition were also trailblazers for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. They broke down barriers and stereotypes, becoming one of the first black groups to achieve mainstream success and helping pave the way for other black artists to do the same.

Despite changes in the music industry and the passing of time, New Edition continues to make music and tour, inspiring and entertaining audiences around the world. They will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential groups in the history of R&B and pop music.

21. Patti LaBelle

Patti LaBelle is a legendary R&B singer known for her powerhouse vocals and dynamic stage presence. With hits like “Lady Marmalade,” “If You Asked Me To,” and “On My Own,” LaBelle’s music has been a staple of soul and R&B radio stations for decades.

LaBelle’s music was a reflection of her own experiences and emotions, as well as a celebration of love, relationships, and personal strength. Her powerful voice and soulful delivery captured the hearts of fans around the world, making her one of the most beloved and influential R&B singers of all time.

In addition to her music, Patti LaBelle was also a trailblazer for African American women in the entertainment industry. She broke down barriers and stereotypes, becoming one of the first black female singers to achieve mainstream success and helping pave the way for other black women artists to do the same.

Despite changes in the music industry and the passing of time, Patti LaBelle continues to perform and inspire audiences with her incredible talent and personality. She will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential voices in the history of R&B and soul music.

22. Curtis Mayfield

Curtis Mayfield was a pioneering R&B singer and songwriter known for his socially conscious lyrics and innovative musical style. With hits like “Superfly,” “People Get Ready,” and “Freddie’s Dead,” Mayfield’s music has been a staple of soul and R&B radio stations for decades.

Mayfield’s music was a reflection of his own experiences and observations, as well as a powerful commentary on social and political issues of the time. His innovative use of funk and soul rhythms, along with his poetic and thought-provoking lyrics, helped to redefine the R&B genre and inspired countless artists to follow in his footsteps.

In addition to his music, Curtis Mayfield was also a trailblazer for African American musicians in the entertainment industry. He broke down barriers and stereotypes, becoming one of the first black artists to achieve mainstream success and helping pave the way for other black artists to do the same.

Despite his untimely passing in 1999, Curtis Mayfield’s music continues to inspire and influence generations of musicians and fans around the world. He will always be remembered as one of the most talented and innovative voices in the history of R&B and soul music.

23. The Supremes

The Supremes were a groundbreaking R&B girl group known for their polished harmonies, stylish image, and string of chart-topping hits. With songs like “Baby Love,” “Stop! In the Name of Love,” and “You Can’t Hurry Love,” The Supremes became one of the most successful and influential groups of the 1960s.

The Supremes’ music was a reflection of the changing social landscape of the time, as well as a celebration of love, relationships, and personal empowerment. Their signature sound and sophisticated style helped to redefine the R&B genre and inspired countless artists to follow in their footsteps.

In addition to their music, The Supremes were also trailblazers for women and African Americans in the entertainment industry. They broke down barriers and stereotypes, becoming one of the first black girl groups to achieve mainstream success and helping pave the way for other black artists and women to do the same.

Despite changes in the music industry and the passing of time, The Supremes’ music continues to captivate and inspire audiences around the world. They will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential groups in the history of R&B and pop music.

24. Lionel Richie

Lionel Richie is an iconic R&B singer-songwriter known for his soulful ballads, catchy pop hits, and smooth vocal style. With songs like “Hello,” “All Night Long (All Night),” and “Endless Love,” Richie has become one of the most recognizable and beloved voices in the music industry.

Richie’s music is a reflection of his own experiences and observations, as well as a celebration of love, relationships, and personal growth. His signature sound and heartfelt lyrics have helped to redefine the R&B and pop genres and inspired countless artists to follow in his footsteps.

In addition to his music, Lionel Richie has also been a trailblazer for African American artists in the entertainment industry. He broke down barriers and stereotypes, becoming one of the first black artists to achieve mainstream success and helping pave the way for other black artists to do the same.

Despite changes in the music industry and the passing of time, Lionel Richie’s music continues to resonate with audiences around the world. He will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential voices in the history of R&B and pop music.

25. Mary J. Blige

Mary J. Blige, often referred to as the “Queen of Hip-Hop Soul,” is a multi-talented R&B singer, songwriter, actress, and philanthropist. With songs like “Real Love,” “Family Affair,” and “No More Drama,” Blige has become one of the most respected and influential artists in the music industry.

Blige’s music is a reflection of her own experiences and struggles, as well as a celebration of love, relationships, and personal growth. Her signature sound and powerful vocals have helped to redefine the R&B and hip-hop genres and inspired countless artists to follow in her footsteps.

In addition to her music, Mary J. Blige has also been a strong advocate for social justice and women’s empowerment. She has used her platform to speak out against issues like domestic violence and inequality, and has supported numerous charitable causes over the years.

Despite changes in the music industry and the passing of time, Mary J. Blige’s music and impact continue to inspire and uplift audiences around the world. She will always be remembered as one of the most talented and influential voices in the history of R&B and hip-hop music.

26. Sade Adu

Sade Adu, simply known as Sade, is a British-Nigerian singer, songwriter, and composer who has achieved global recognition for her soulful and soothing music. Her music is a blend of R&B, soul, jazz, and soft rock, and is characterized by her smooth vocals, emotive lyrics, and subtle instrumental arrangements.

Sade’s music is a reflection of her own experiences and observations, and her songs often explore themes of love, loss, and self-discovery. Her iconic hits, such as “Smooth Operator,” “No Ordinary Love,” and “The Sweetest Taboo,” have become timeless classics that continue to resonate with audiences around the world.

In addition to her music, Sade Adu is also known for her effortless style and iconic fashion sense. She has been a role model for women across generations, inspiring them to embrace their unique beauty and style.

Despite the passing of time, Sade’s music remains as relevant and captivating as ever, and she continues to be celebrated as one of the most talented and influential artists in the history of R&B and soul music.

27. The Weeknd

The Weeknd, born Abel Makkonen Tesfaye, is a Canadian singer, songwriter, and record producer who has risen to fame in recent years for his unique blend of R&B, pop, and electronic music. His music is characterized by his falsetto vocals, moody lyrics, and atmospheric soundscapes, which have earned him critical acclaim and a devoted fan base.

The Weeknd’s music often explores themes of love, lust, and drug use, and his songs are known for their raw and confessional nature. His hits, such as “Can’t Feel My Face,” “Starboy,” and “Blinding Lights,” have become chart-topping successes around the world, solidifying his position as one of the most popular and influential artists of his generation.

In addition to his music, The Weeknd is also known for his distinctive style and aesthetic, which often incorporates elements of goth, glam, and vintage fashion. He has been praised for his bold and experimental approach to both music and fashion, inspiring a new generation of artists to push boundaries and break new ground.

Despite his success and fame, The Weeknd remains committed to creating meaningful and authentic music that resonates with his fans. He continues to evolve and innovate as an artist, pushing the boundaries of R&B and pop music and cementing his place as one of the most important voices in contemporary music.

28. Diana Ross

Diana Ross is an American singer, actress, and record producer who has had a long and illustrious career spanning several decades. She first rose to fame as the lead singer of the Supremes, one of the most successful girl groups of all time, before embarking on a successful solo career in the 1970s.

Diana Ross’s music is a blend of R&B, soul, pop, and disco, and is characterized by her powerful vocals, infectious melodies, and catchy hooks. Her iconic hits, such as “Ain’t No Mountain High Enough,” “I’m Coming Out,” and “Upside Down,” have become timeless classics that continue to be celebrated by fans around the world.

In addition to her music, Diana Ross is also known for her acting career, which has included starring roles in films such as “Lady Sings the Blues” and “The Wiz.” She has also been a trailblazer for African American women in the entertainment industry, using her platform to advocate for diversity and representation.

Despite her many accomplishments, Diana Ross remains a humble and gracious artist, dedicated to creating music that inspires and uplifts her fans. She continues to be celebrated as a cultural icon and a symbol of excellence in the world of R&B and pop music.

29. Commodores

The Commodores are an American funk/soul band that rose to prominence in the 1970s and 80s. The band originally formed at Tuskegee University in Alabama, and quickly gained a following with their energetic and soulful live performances.

The Commodores’ music is characterized by their tight grooves, funky basslines, and smooth vocal harmonies. Their hits, such as “Brick House,” “Easy,” and “Nightshift,” have become enduring classics of the R&B and funk genres, and have been covered and sampled by numerous artists over the years.

In addition to their music, the Commodores are also known for their dynamic stage presence and showmanship. They have toured extensively around the world, entertaining audiences with their electrifying performances and infectious energy.

Despite changes in lineup over the years, the Commodores have remained a beloved and influential force in the world of R&B and funk music. They continue to inspire and entertain fans with their timeless music and electrifying live shows, cementing their place as one of the most iconic bands of their era.

30. Aaliyah

Aaliyah was an American R&B singer, actress, and model who rose to fame in the 1990s. Known for her smooth and sultry vocals, Aaliyah’s music was a unique blend of R&B, hip-hop, and pop, and she quickly became one of the most iconic artists of her time.

Aaliyah’s hits, such as “Are You That Somebody,” “Rock the Boat,” and “Try Again,” showcased her incredible vocal range and ability to blend genres seamlessly. Her music was not only popular, but also groundbreaking, as she broke down barriers and paved the way for other female artists in the industry.

In addition to her music, Aaliyah was also a successful actress, appearing in films such as “Romeo Must Die” and “Queen of the Damned.” Her talent, beauty, and charisma made her a beloved and influential figure in both the music and entertainment worlds.

Tragically, Aaliyah’s life was cut short in a plane crash in 2001, at the age of just 22. Despite her untimely death, her music and legacy continue to inspire and influence new generations of artists, cementing her place as one of the greatest R&B artists of all time.

31. B.B. King

B.B. King, also known as the “King of Blues,” was an American blues singer, songwriter, and guitarist. With his distinctive guitar playing style and powerful vocals, King became one of the most influential and celebrated blues musicians of all time.

Born in Mississippi in 1925, King began his music career in the 1940s, performing in small clubs and on the radio. He soon gained a following for his electrifying live performances, which combined his soulful vocals with his mastery of the guitar.

King’s music was characterized by his powerful and expressive guitar playing, which often featured intricate and emotive solos. His hits, such as “The Thrill is Gone,” “Sweet Little Angel,” and “Lucille,” have become timeless classics of the blues genre, and have inspired countless musicians over the years.

In addition to his music, King was also a vocal advocate for racial equality and social justice, using his platform to speak out against discrimination and injustice. His contributions to music and society have earned him numerous accolades, including induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and the Blues Hall of Fame.

Although King passed away in 2015, his music and legacy continue to inspire and influence new generations of musicians, cementing his place as one of the greatest blues artists of all time.

32. Etta James

Etta James was an American singer and songwriter known for her powerful voice and eclectic musical style. Born in Los Angeles in 1938, James began her music career in the 1950s, quickly gaining a reputation as a talented and versatile singer.

James’ music was a blend of R&B, soul, blues, and rock, and her voice was capable of delivering everything from soft, soulful ballads to hard-hitting, bluesy rockers. Her hits, such as “At Last,” “I’d Rather Go Blind,” and “Something’s Got a Hold on Me,” have become classics of the genre and continue to be celebrated today.

In addition to her music career, James was also known for her struggles with addiction and personal difficulties, which she often documented in her music. Her raw and honest approach to songwriting has made her an inspiration to countless artists and fans around the world.

Despite facing numerous obstacles throughout her life, James continued to create music that resonated with audiences and helped to shape the sound of modern R&B and soul. Her legacy as a pioneering and influential artist continues to be celebrated today, cementing her place as one of the most iconic voices in American music history.

33. Chris Brown

Chris Brown is an American singer, songwriter, dancer, and actor who rose to fame in the mid-2000s with his debut single “Run It!” His smooth vocals and impressive dance moves quickly made him a fan favorite, and he has since become one of the biggest names in contemporary R&B.

Over the years, Brown has released numerous hit songs, including “With You,” “Forever,” and “Loyal,” and has collaborated with some of the biggest names in the industry. He has also won numerous awards for his music, including a Grammy Award for Best R&B Album in 2012 for his album “F.A.M.E.”

Despite his success, Brown has faced controversy throughout his career, including legal issues and personal struggles. However, he has continued to be a dominant force in the music industry, with his unique style and undeniable talent setting him apart from his peers.

In addition to his music career, Brown has also dabbled in acting, appearing in films such as “Stomp the Yard” and “Takers.” His numerous talents and ability to connect with fans have made him a true icon of modern R&B.

34. Donny Hathaway

Donny Hathaway was an American singer, songwriter, and pianist who was known for his soulful voice and exceptional musical abilities. Born in Chicago in 1945, Hathaway began his music career in the 1960s, working as a session musician and songwriter for various labels.

Hathaway’s music was a unique blend of soul, R&B, jazz, and gospel, and his emotive voice and intricate piano playing quickly set him apart from his peers. He released several successful albums throughout the 1970s, including “Everything Is Everything” and “Extension of a Man,” which contained hit songs such as “The Ghetto” and “Someday We’ll All Be Free.”

Despite his success, Hathaway faced personal struggles throughout his life, including battles with mental illness and addiction. Tragically, he passed away in 1979 at the age of 33, leaving behind a legacy as one of the greatest voices in R&B history.

Hathaway’s music continues to be celebrated today, with his influence felt across multiple genres. His powerful voice and poignant lyrics continue to inspire artists and fans alike, cementing his place as a true icon of soul and R&B music.

35. Usher

Usher is an American singer, songwriter, and dancer who rose to fame in the late 1990s with his smooth vocals and electrifying performances. Born in Dallas, Texas in 1978, Usher’s family moved to Atlanta when he was a child, where he began singing in local church choirs.

In the early 1990s, Usher landed a recording contract with LaFace Records and released his self-titled debut album in 1994. However, it wasn’t until his second album, “My Way,” in 1997 that Usher became a mainstream success. The album featured hit singles such as “Nice & Slow” and “You Make Me Wanna…” and established Usher as a rising star in the R&B world.

Usher’s music continued to evolve throughout the 2000s, with albums such as “Confessions” and “8701” showcasing his versatility and growth as an artist. He has won numerous awards throughout his career, including eight Grammy Awards and 18 Billboard Music Awards.

In addition to his music career, Usher has also made a name for himself as an actor, appearing in films such as “She’s All That” and “In the Mix.” He has also been involved in various philanthropic efforts, including the establishment of the Usher’s New Look Foundation, which helps underprivileged youth achieve their dreams.

Today, Usher remains one of the most influential and respected figures in R&B, with a catalog of hits that has secured his place in music history.

36. Barry White

Barry White was an American singer, songwriter, and composer who was known for his deep, soulful voice and romantic ballads. Born in Texas in 1944, White began his music career in the 1960s as a producer and songwriter for various R&B and soul artists.

White’s solo career took off in the 1970s with the release of his album “I’ve Got So Much to Give” in 1973. The album included hit singles such as “I’m Gonna Love You Just a Little More Baby” and “Never, Never Gonna Give You Up,” which showcased his signature sound and romantic lyrics.

Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, White continued to release successful albums and singles, including the popular song “Can’t Get Enough of Your Love, Babe.” He also collaborated with other musicians and produced music for various films and TV shows.

In addition to his music career, White was also a philanthropist and community activist, and worked to promote education and social justice in his hometown of Los Angeles.

White’s legacy as one of the most iconic and influential R&B artists of all time continues to live on today, and his music remains a beloved staple of the genre.

37. Mariah Carey

Mariah Carey is an American singer, songwriter, and actress who is known for her powerful vocals, impressive vocal range, and chart-topping hits. Born in New York in 1969, Carey began her music career in the late 1980s with the release of her self-titled debut album in 1990.

Carey’s music has spanned various genres over the years, including pop, R&B, hip-hop, and gospel. She has released numerous successful albums and singles, including hits such as “Vision of Love,” “Emotions,” “Fantasy,” and “We Belong Together.” Her music has earned her numerous accolades and awards, including multiple Grammy Awards.

In addition to her music career, Carey has also dabbled in acting, appearing in several films and television shows over the years. She has also been involved in various philanthropic efforts, including her own organization, the Fresh Air Fund, which provides summer camp opportunities for underprivileged children.

Despite facing various personal and professional challenges throughout her career, Carey’s talent and impact on the music industry remain undeniable. She continues to inspire and influence countless artists and fans around the world.

38. Chaka Khan

Chaka Khan, born Yvette Marie Stevens, is an American singer-songwriter and musician who is widely known for her powerful voice, bold style, and infectious energy. She rose to fame in the 1970s as the frontwoman for the funk band Rufus, with hits such as “Tell Me Something Good” and “Ain’t Nobody.”

Over the course of her career, Khan has won 10 Grammy Awards and sold over 70 million records worldwide. She has also collaborated with a wide range of artists across different genres, including Prince, Mary J. Blige, and Whitney Houston, among others.

Beyond her music career, Khan has been involved in various humanitarian and philanthropic efforts, including supporting organizations that focus on issues such as domestic violence, education, and HIV/AIDS. In 2011, she established the Chaka Khan Foundation to support education, empowerment, and advocacy initiatives for at-risk youth and women.

With her powerful voice and captivating presence, Khan continues to inspire generations of artists and fans alike. She remains a true icon in the world of R&B and beyond.

39. The O’Jays

The O’Jays are an American R&B group that formed in Canton, Ohio in the late 1950s. The group originally consisted of Eddie Levert, Walter Williams, William Powell, Bobby Massey, and Bill Isles, and they became known for their soulful harmonies and energetic live performances.

Throughout their career, The O’Jays have released numerous hit songs, including “Love Train,” “Back Stabbers,” and “For the Love of Money,” among others. Their music often tackles social and political issues, and they have been credited with using their platform to raise awareness about important issues.

The O’Jays have been inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and have received numerous awards and accolades for their contributions to music. They have also inspired many other artists in the R&B and soul genres with their timeless sound and powerful performances.

Despite lineup changes over the years, The O’Jays continue to tour and record music, and they remain beloved by fans around the world for their soulful sound and positive messages.

40. TLC

TLC is an American R&B girl group that rose to fame in the early 1990s. The group, which consists of Tionne “T-Boz” Watkins, Lisa “Left Eye” Lopes, and Rozonda “Chilli” Thomas, is known for their unique blend of R&B, hip-hop, and pop music.

TLC’s music often tackles themes of female empowerment and relationships, and their innovative music videos and fashion choices helped to shape the style of the era. Their hits include “Waterfalls,” “No Scrubs,” and “Creep,” among many others.

Despite the tragic loss of Left Eye in a car accident in 2002, TLC continued to make music and tour as a duo, with the remaining members releasing their final album in 2017. Their influence on the R&B genre is undeniable, and their music continues to inspire and resonate with fans around the world.

41. Alicia Keys

Alicia Keys is a multi-talented musician, songwriter, and actress known for her soulful voice and unique blend of R&B, jazz, and hip-hop. With over 65 million records sold worldwide, she has become one of the best-selling artists of all time.

In addition to her impressive music career, Alicia Keys is also a successful actress, having appeared in films such as “The Secret Life of Bees” and “Smokin’ Aces.” She is also a passionate philanthropist, known for her work with various charitable organizations.

Alicia Keys’ music often explores themes of love, empowerment, and social justice. Her hits include “Fallin’,” “No One,” and “Empire State of Mind,” among many others. She is a talented pianist and often incorporates her piano playing into her performances.

With numerous awards and accolades to her name, including 15 Grammy Awards, Alicia Keys continues to be a powerful force in the music industry, inspiring fans with her music and dedication to social causes.

42. Lauryn Hill

Lauryn Hill is a singer, rapper, songwriter, and actress known for her distinctive voice and genre-blending music that incorporates elements of R&B, hip-hop, and reggae. She first gained fame as a member of the group The Fugees before embarking on a successful solo career.

As a solo artist, Lauryn Hill released her debut album “The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill” in 1998, which became a critical and commercial success. The album features a mix of soulful ballads and hip-hop tracks, exploring themes of love, spirituality, and social justice. It won several Grammy Awards, including Album of the Year, making Hill the first woman to win that award as a solo artist.

In addition to her music career, Lauryn Hill is also an accomplished actress, having appeared in films such as “Sister Act 2: Back in the Habit” and “The Preacher’s Wife.”

Known for her powerful vocals and socially conscious lyrics, Lauryn Hill continues to be an influential figure in the music industry. Despite a relatively small discography, her impact on R&B and hip-hop cannot be overstated.

43. Roberta Flack

Roberta Flack is a legendary R&B singer and pianist known for her soulful ballads and emotive performances. She first rose to prominence in the 1970s with hit songs such as “Killing Me Softly With His Song” and “The First Time Ever I Saw Your Face”.

Flack’s music is characterized by her smooth, velvety voice and her skillful piano playing. Her songs often explore themes of love, heartbreak, and relationships, and she is known for her ability to convey deep emotion through her music.

In addition to her successful music career, Flack is also an accomplished musician and has collaborated with other artists such as Donny Hathaway and Peabo Bryson. She has won several Grammy Awards throughout her career and has been inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame.

Roberta Flack remains a beloved figure in the R&B world and her music continues to inspire and move audiences today. Her talent and contributions to the genre have solidified her place as one of the most important and influential R&B artists of all time.

44. Maxwell

Maxwell is a critically acclaimed R&B singer known for his soulful voice and smooth, laid-back style. He burst onto the scene in the mid-1990s with his debut album “Maxwell’s Urban Hang Suite,” which quickly gained widespread popularity for its innovative blend of R&B, soul, and jazz.

Maxwell’s music is characterized by his silky vocals and his ability to craft sensual, introspective ballads that speak to the complexities of love and relationships. His songs often explore themes of vulnerability, longing, and self-discovery, and he is known for his skillful storytelling and emotional depth.

Over the course of his career, Maxwell has earned multiple Grammy Awards and has collaborated with a wide range of artists, including Alicia Keys, Common, and Nas. He is also a respected producer and songwriter, having worked on projects for other artists such as Beyoncé and Mary J. Blige.

Today, Maxwell is widely regarded as one of the most influential R&B artists of his generation, and his music continues to inspire and captivate listeners around the world.

45. Jackie Wilson

Jackie Wilson was a legendary R&B singer known for his electrifying performances and soulful voice. He rose to fame in the 1950s with hits like “Reet Petite” and “Lonely Teardrops,” which helped establish him as one of the genre’s most talented and dynamic performers.

Wilson’s music was characterized by his impressive vocal range and his ability to effortlessly blend elements of R&B, pop, and rock and roll. He was also a skilled dancer, and his energetic performances were known to leave audiences mesmerized and breathless.

In addition to his success as a performer, Wilson was also a prolific songwriter and producer, and he collaborated with a wide range of artists over the course of his career. He continued to record and perform until his untimely death in 1984, and his music has had a lasting impact on the world of R&B and beyond.

Today, Jackie Wilson is remembered as one of the greatest R&B performers of all time, and his music continues to inspire new generations of artists and fans alike.

46. Jodeci

Jodeci was a groundbreaking R&B group that emerged in the early 1990s, known for their fusion of soulful harmonies, hip-hop beats, and sensual lyrics. The group was made up of two sets of brothers, K-Ci and JoJo Hailey and DeVante Swing and Mr. Dalvin, and their unique sound quickly made them one of the most influential acts of their time.

Jodeci’s music was characterized by its raw emotion and soulful sensuality, which was a departure from the polished and more mainstream sound of contemporary R&B. Their hits, such as “Forever My Lady” and “Come and Talk to Me,” showcased their powerful vocals and undeniable chemistry, which quickly made them a fan favorite.

Throughout their career, Jodeci continued to push the boundaries of R&B, experimenting with different sounds and styles while remaining true to their roots. Their impact on the genre can still be felt today, with many contemporary R&B artists citing them as a major influence.

Despite some setbacks and breaks in their career, Jodeci remains a beloved and influential group in the world of R&B, with their music continuing to inspire new generations of fans and artists alike.

47. Toni Braxton

Toni Braxton is a legendary R&B icon known for her soulful voice and heart-wrenching ballads. Her powerful vocals and emotive lyrics have captivated audiences for over two decades. Braxton’s music is a blend of R&B, soul, and pop, with hits like “Un-Break My Heart,” “You’re Making Me High,” and “Breathe Again” becoming timeless classics. Her music speaks to the depths of the human experience, exploring themes of love, heartbreak, and resilience.

Beyond her incredible musical talent, Braxton is also an accomplished actress and television personality. She has starred in Broadway productions, reality shows, and films, showcasing her versatility and range. Braxton’s magnetic presence and undeniable talent have earned her numerous awards and accolades, including seven Grammy Awards and a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

Despite facing numerous challenges throughout her career, including health issues and personal struggles, Braxton remains a beloved and respected figure in the music industry. Her music continues to inspire and resonate with fans around the world, cementing her status as a true R&B icon.

48. Beyoncé

Beyoncé is a global superstar and one of the most iconic figures in modern R&B music. With her incredible vocal range, dynamic stage presence, and impeccable artistry, Beyoncé has become a household name and a true inspiration to millions of fans around the world.

As a solo artist, Beyoncé has released several critically acclaimed albums, including “Dangerously in Love,” “B’Day,” and “Lemonade.” Her music often explores themes of empowerment, love, and the black experience, with hits like “Crazy in Love,” “Single Ladies,” and “Formation” becoming cultural touchstones.

Beyond her music, Beyoncé is also an accomplished actress, fashion icon, and philanthropist. She has starred in films like Dreamgirls and The Lion King, and has also used her platform to advocate for social justice and support various charitable causes.

Throughout her career, Beyoncé has broken countless records and earned numerous accolades, including 28 Grammy Awards, making her the most decorated female artist in Grammy history. Her influence on R&B and pop music is undeniable, and her impact on popular culture as a whole continues to be felt.

49. Sly & the Family Stone

Sly & the Family Stone were a groundbreaking R&B group that helped to define the sound of the late 1960s and early 1970s. Led by the charismatic Sly Stone, the group blended R&B, funk, rock, and psychedelic music to create a unique and influential sound.

Sly & the Family Stone’s music was characterized by its infectious grooves, uplifting messages, and celebratory spirit. Hits like “Dance to the Music,” “Everyday People,” and “Thank You (Falettinme Be Mice Elf Agin)” became anthems for a generation, inspiring listeners to embrace their differences and come together in unity.

In addition to their musical achievements, Sly & the Family Stone were also pioneers in promoting racial and gender diversity within the music industry. Their racially integrated and gender-mixed lineup was groundbreaking for its time and paved the way for future generations of artists.

Despite facing numerous personal and professional challenges over the years, including substance abuse and legal issues, Sly & the Family Stone’s legacy as a trailblazing and influential R&B group remains secure. Their music continues to inspire and uplift listeners around the world, cementing their place in the pantheon of great R&B artists.

50. Frank Ocean

Frank Ocean is a multi-talented R&B artist known for his innovative approach to music and storytelling. With his distinctive falsetto voice and introspective lyrics, Ocean has become a leading voice in contemporary R&B and a celebrated figure in popular culture.

Ocean’s music explores themes of love, identity, and personal growth, with his critically acclaimed albums “Channel Orange” and “Blonde” showcasing his artistry and versatility. His songs are characterized by their emotional depth, intricate arrangements, and cinematic quality, with hits like “Thinkin Bout You,” “Pyramids,” and “Nights” becoming instant classics.

Beyond his music, Ocean is also a respected songwriter, producer, and visual artist. He has collaborated with numerous artists across genres and mediums, including Jay-Z, Tyler, The Creator, and Spike Jonze, among others. His work often pushes boundaries and challenges conventional ideas about what R&B music can be.

Despite being known for his elusive public persona and rare live performances, Frank Ocean’s impact on R&B and popular culture cannot be denied. His music continues to inspire and resonate with fans around the world, cementing his status as one of the most important and influential R&B artists of his generation.
